CASE 47:
WHEN TO SECTION A PATIENT UNDER THE MENTAL
HEALTH ACT
Kate is 27 and lives at home with her parents and younger brother. She studied a nthropology
at university and had been in a long-term relationship. After leaving university with a good
degree, she struggled to get a job. She eventually found work in a restaurant, which she
seemed to enjoy. Last year her boyfriend moved out and she decided to quit her job and move
back home. Over the past year her family has become increasingly worried about her health
and behaviour. Her personal care has deteriorated and she has slowly withdrawn from inter-
acting with her family. She has not bothered to find a job locally and only leaves her bedroom
to wash and get food from the kitchen. Kate has also begun to clean her hands obsessively
although otherwise she does not seem to wash. Her room smells stale and she has refused to
let her mum change her bedding. She does not seem to change her clothes and does not allow
them to be washed with the family clothes. Her mother has noticed that Kate’s hands are raw
and that she has sores on her back and her legs. She refused to speak to a GP about her mood,
and in desperation Kate’s parents have spoken to their GP about what can be done. The GP
was concerned enough to attempt a home visit, but on arrival Kate refused to come out of her
room, saying that she was just having a break from the stresses of living.
Questions
• Could Kate be detained for assessment or treatment under the Mental Health Act?
• Should Kate be detained for assessment or treatment under the Mental Health Act?

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman lives with her parents. Over the past year she has become increasingly isolated and spends most days in her bedroom. Her hygiene has deteriorated. She rarely changes clothes and refuses to let anyone wash her bedding. She washes her hands repetitively and they are cracked and bleeding. Her mother has noticed sores on her back and legs. She has stopped working and will not attend appointments. During a home visit, she will not open the door and speaks through it. She says she is “fine” and does not want help. She denies suicidal intent, but her family reports she is eating little and appears confused at times. The clinician worries about untreated psychosis or severe depression with self-neglect. Hospital policy and state law allow either emergency detention for psychiatric evaluation or continued community management in this situation. A decision is needed today because the family will be away and cannot monitor her.
data.choice_1: Initiate involuntary psychiatric detention for urgent assessment
data.choice_2: Do not detain and arrange intensive outpatient follow-up

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Rebalance the clinical framing so the ethical tension is not resolved by implying clear clinical necessity for detention. Edit phrases like “appears confused at times” and “clinician worries about untreated psychosis or severe depression” to be more equivocal (e.g., “family sometimes interprets her as ‘distracted’ or ‘overwhelmed’; clinician cannot fully assess thought process at the door”). Add concrete facts that make outpatient management clinically defensible (e.g., she is speaking coherently, denies hallucinations and suicidality, can state her name/date/location, agrees to a same-day telepsychiatry visit or allows a nurse to assess wounds). Add concrete harms/risks of detention (e.g., history of trauma, prior involuntary hold was destabilizing, may damage trust and reduce future engagement). Remove/soften any wording that implies detention is the medically ‘correct’ option.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or tighten details that do not change the decision, and add missing decision-critical facts. Consider condensing repetitive isolation/hygiene details into 1–2 sentences. Add essential safety/medical context: vitals/appearance if observed, whether she has access to food/water, capacity indicators (orientation, ability to explain choices), whether there is immediate medical concern for infected wounds, and what ‘intensive outpatient follow-up’ concretely means (mobile crisis team today, daily visits, telehealth, APS involvement). Clarify whether the clinician has direct visual assessment or only collateral information from family.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the operational pathway for an involuntary evaluation when the patient will not open the door (e.g., mobile crisis team with law enforcement for a welfare check; criteria for emergency hold based on collateral plus limited assessment). Specify the setting (home visit by community psychiatry/primary care/mobile crisis) and how outpatient follow-up would be implemented given her refusal to attend appointments (e.g., assertive community treatment, home-based visits). Ensure the described skin findings (cracked bleeding hands, sores) are linked to plausible causes (compulsive washing/skin picking/pressure sores) and indicate whether urgent medical evaluation is needed.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the accumulation of severe self-neglect (bleeding hands, sores, eating little, confusion, refusing contact) makes detention feel like the obvious safer choice. To make both options genuinely defensible, add countervailing facts supporting outpatient care (e.g., she accepts food delivery, takes prescribed meds, permits a brief doorway assessment, agrees to daily mobile crisis visits, has no delirium/red flags for imminent medical collapse). Also add ethically meaningful downsides to detention beyond generic ‘loss of freedom’ (e.g., high likelihood of traumatic restraint, risk of worsening paranoia, cultural/personal reasons she fears hospitals). Keep stakes high while making the clinician’s uncertainty about imminent danger and decision-making capacity credible.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so outpatient management is ethically/clinically defensible and detention is not the clearly safer default. For example: (1) Clarify she is oriented, can state a consistent plan for food/hydration and wound care, and there is no evidence of immediate medical instability; (2) Add concrete, credible supports that could substitute for family monitoring (e.g., mobile crisis team visits twice daily, same-day psychiatric appointment, home health for skin lesions, safety plan, ability to call/return if she deteriorates). (3) Add meaningful harms of detention (e.g., prior traumatic involuntary hospitalization, high likelihood of restraint/seclusion due to contamination fears, risk of losing housing/employment/insurance, mistrust that could sever future engagement). (4) Alternatively, if you want to keep high concern for incapacity/self-neglect, reduce the ‘imminent danger’ cues (remove ‘confused at times’ or ‘eating little’ or clarify these are family impressions without verification) so the threshold for emergency detention is genuinely ambiguous.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce loaded or one-sided framing that nudges toward detention. Replace repeated pejorative phrasing (e.g., "refuses"/"will not") with neutral descriptions ("declines," "does not engage"). Balance the portrayal by adding 1–2 clinically relevant facts that could support outpatient management (e.g., family able to return tomorrow, patient intermittently accepts food/fluids, no evidence of imminent harm, agrees to speak briefly by phone), so neither option reads as obviously safer.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Rewrite in a more clinical consult-note style and add minimal key exam elements. Specify pertinent mental status findings available through the door (speech latency, thought content, orientation), any available vitals/medical red flags, and an explicit capacity/"grave disability" concern. Use standard terms (ADL impairment, self-neglect, possible psychosis vs severe major depressive episode with catatonic features vs OCD) rather than lay descriptors.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten repetitive details and ensure each detail maps to decision stakes. Condense hygiene/bedding/handwashing into one sentence (e.g., "marked ADL decline with poor hygiene, contaminated bedding, and compulsive handwashing causing skin breakdown"). Clarify the decision threshold by stating what criterion is being debated today (e.g., whether current self-neglect/confusion meets emergency detention standard) and remove minor details that do not change that threshold.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Soften potentially graphic descriptors while keeping clinical meaning. Replace "cracked and bleeding" with "excoriated with skin breakdown" and "sores" with "superficial skin lesions/pressure-related skin breakdown"; avoid vivid injury language. Keep discussion of self-neglect and nutrition in clinical terms (reduced oral intake, possible dehydration/malnutrition) without graphic elaboration.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make each choice a complete, parallel action statement in ~10–15 words without extra implementation detail. For example: (1) "Place an emergency involuntary hold for immediate psychiatric evaluation in hospital." (2) "Defer involuntary hold and implement same-day intensive community crisis follow-up." Ensure both specify timing (today) and level of response (emergency hold vs crisis/outpatient pathway).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 (no detention) more clinically/ethically defensible by reducing cues of imminent medical danger/incapacity (e.g., remove/soften “eating little,” “confused at times,” “sores,” “cracked and bleeding” or clarify they are superficial and she is maintaining hydration/nutrition). Alternatively, if keeping severity, add concrete, weighty harms of detention (e.g., prior trauma with restraint, loss of housing/employment/immigration consequence, strong therapeutic alliance risk) and add factors suggesting she might engage voluntarily (e.g., agrees to telehealth, will speak with mobile crisis through the door). Also balance framing so neither option reads like the medically ‘correct’ one.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle options: specify that same-day mobile crisis outreach/home-based evaluation is unavailable, EMS welfare-check cannot enter without a detention order, and adult protective services cannot respond today; or explicitly state that you already attempted these and they failed. Clarify that the only two legally actionable choices *today* are to file for emergency detention vs leave her in the community with a specific intensive plan.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The vignette currently implies policy/law ‘allow either’ despite signs that could meet common involuntary-hold criteria (grave disability/self-neglect). Reframe to show genuine ambiguity about whether legal/clinical criteria are met: add that she is oriented, denies hallucinations, can articulate a plan for food/safety, and there is uncertainty about capacity; or state that the jurisdiction’s threshold is unclear in self-neglect cases and both pathways are permissible under policy. Otherwise, if she clearly cannot care for herself, it becomes a standards-based decision rather than a gray-zone ethical dilemma.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman has had a year of worsening social withdrawal and marked decline in self-care. Her parents report poor hygiene, unchanged bedding, and repetitive handwashing with skin breakdown. They have seen a few superficial skin lesions that look like irritation rather than infection. You make a home visit, but she speaks through the closed door and declines entry. Her speech is coherent. She states her name, the date, and where she is. She denies suicidal intent, hallucinations, and substance use. She says she has food and water in her room, will accept meals left outside the door, and agrees to a same-day video visit if scheduled. She refuses hospital care and says she will not open the door for EMS. A prior involuntary hospitalization was traumatic for her, and her contamination fears raise concern she could require restraint if detained. Hospital policy and state law permit either pathway in this gray-zone situation. A decision is needed today because her parents are leaving town, and same-day mobile crisis or adult protective services cannot respond.
data.choice_1: File for emergency involuntary detention for immediate psychiatric evaluation today
data.choice_2: Defer detention and proceed with same-day intensive community-based follow-up

choice_1.choice: File for emergency involuntary detention for immediate psychiatric evaluation today

choice_2.choice: Defer detention and proceed with same-day intensive community-based follow-up

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one concrete indicator that she is medically/psychiatrically unsafe at home today (e.g., significant weight loss/dehydration, inability to obtain food/water, infected skin breakdown, or escalating psychosis), making immediate evaluation clearly beneficial; and/or add a clause that intensive community follow-up is likely to fail or be delayed (e.g., she has a history of not engaging/ending video visits, parents cannot leave meals, or no clinician can enter), so deferring detention clearly risks worsening health.

Add one clause clarifying imminent harm risk if not detained (e.g., "parents report she has eaten almost nothing for 3 days / has worsening dehydration"), and one clause clarifying likely iatrogenic harm from detention (e.g., "last detention required physical restraint and caused injury/lasting trauma").

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman has had a year of worsening social withdrawal and marked decline in self-care. Her parents report poor hygiene, unchanged bedding, and repetitive handwashing with skin breakdown. Over the past week, they report visible weight loss and little food or fluid intake. You make a home visit, but she speaks through the closed door and declines entry. Her speech is coherent. She states her name, the date, and where she is. She denies suicidal intent, hallucinations, and substance use. She says she has limited food and water in her room. She will accept meals left outside the door. She agrees to a same-day video visit, but she has recently ended video visits early and has not answered follow-up calls. She refuses hospital care and will not open the door for EMS. A prior involuntary hospitalization required physical restraint and caused injury and lasting trauma. Her contamination fears raise concern she could require restraint again if detained. Her parents are leaving town today, and same-day mobile crisis or adult protective services cannot respond. Hospital policy and state law permit either pathway in this gray-zone situation.

choice_1.choice: File for emergency involuntary detention for immediate psychiatric evaluation today

choice_2.choice: Defer detention and proceed with same-day intensive community-based follow-up
